metadata.case_name: Khardah & Co. Ltd. v. Raymon & Co. (India) Ltd.

facts.text: Appellants own a Jute Mill at Calcutta and carry on the business of manufacture and sale of Jute.

On September 7, 1955, appellants entered into a contract with respondents (dealers in jute) for purchase of 750 bales of Jute cutting raw of Pakistan at Rs. 80 per bale of 400 lbs., to be delivered in October, November and December at 250 bales every month.
Clause 14 of the agreement provides that all disputes arising out of or concerning the contract should be referred to arbitration of the Bengal Chamber of Commerce.
Respondents failed to deliver the goods as agreed.
Appellants applied to Bengal Chamber of Commerce for arbitration per Cl. 14.
Respondents appeared before arbitrators and contested the claim on merits.
Arbitrators made award in favour of appellants for Rs. 41,250 with interest.
Award filed under s.14(2) of Indian Arbitration Act in Calcutta High Court original side; notice issued to respondents.

Respondents filed application in High Court under s.33 Arbitration Act praying declaration that contract dated Sept 7, 1955 illegal as contravening Central Govt notification dated Oct 29, 1953; award void.
Learned Judge on original side dismissed respondents' application, passed decree in terms of award.

Respondents appealed to Division Bench (Appeals Nos. 173 and 151 of 1957? Text has 173 and 151, earlier 154 and 173). Chakravartti CJ and Lahiri J held contract illegal per notification, allowed appeals, set aside award.
Appellants obtained certificate under Art. 133(1) Constitution; appeals to Supreme Court.

Central Government notification dated Oct 29, 1953 under s.17 Forward Contracts Regulation Act, 1952 prohibiting forward contracts other than non-transferable specific delivery contracts for raw jute.
Appellants held import licences No. A/062290/52 and A/063733/52, non-transferable, for raw jute from Pakistan for consumption in their factory, not to be sold.
On Sept 26, 1955, appellants requested letter of authority under licence A/062290/52 for respondents (Raymon Co. India Ltd.) for 2500 maunds jute cuttings from Narayanganj, East Pakistan.
Letter of authority received Sept 29, 1955 (text says 1956, likely typo), sent to respondents for Contract No. 2306 (the Sept 7 contract).
Respondents opened letter of credit in East Pakistan bank on strength of letter of authority; goods imported.

legal_issues.text: Whether the arbitration clause covers dispute on validity/illegality of the contract, or whether court can decide under s.33 Arbitration Act.
Whether respondents estopped from challenging award by appearing before arbitrators.

Whether the contract dated Sept 7, 1955 is illegal as contravening notification dated Oct 29, 1953, specifically whether it is a non-transferable specific delivery contract exempt under s.18(1) Forward Contracts Regulation Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Arbitration clause wide enough to include dispute on validity of contract; respondents can only challenge award under ss.15,16,30 Arbitration Act, not s.33 for declaration of illegality.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Cl.14 contract; Ruby General Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Pearey Lal Kumar

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents estopped from questioning award validity by submitting to arbitrators' jurisdiction.
Contract is non-transferable specific delivery contract within s.2(f) Forward Contracts Regulation Act, not hit by notification.

respondent_arguments.text: Contract illegal and void ab initio as contravening notification dated Oct 29, 1953; arbitration clause perishes with it; proceedings and award void.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.17 Forward Contracts Regulation Act; s.33 Arbitration Act; notification Oct 29, 1953

respondent_arguments.text: Contract transferable; rights/liabilities assignable; not non-transferable specific delivery contract.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.2(f) Forward Contracts Regulation Act (read 'or' as 'and')

court_reasoning.text: Arbitration clause integral part of contract; if contract void ab initio for illegality, clause also void; dispute on existence/validity not for arbitrators but court under s.33.
court_reasoning.key_observation: When whole agreement perishes, parts perish; Heyman v. Darwins Ltd.

court_reasoning.text: No estoppel; appearance before arbitrators does not confer jurisdiction if no valid arbitration agreement; initial want of jurisdiction not cured by acquiescence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Ex p. Wyld distinguished; requires valid submission.

court_reasoning.text: Contract is specific delivery contract; non-transferable as buyers cannot assign rights per import licence; sellers' rights to price burdened by obligation to deliver documents, non-assignable; terms reflect non-transfer intent linked to licence conditions.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Surrounding circumstances including import licence and letter of authority show non-transferability; Cl.3, import licence terms.

holdings.text: Dispute on contract validity/illegality for court, not arbitrators; s.33 application maintainable.
No estoppel by appearance before arbitrators without valid agreement.
Contract non-transferable specific delivery contract per s.2(f); but analysis leans to it being hit or not â€“ text cuts off, but court examines transferability.

precedents_cited.relevance: Arbitration clause void if contract void ab initio for illegality.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ruby General Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Pearey Lal Kumar
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide arbitration clauses include validity disputes.

precedents_cited.case_name: Union of India v. Kishorilal Gupta and Brothers
precedents_cited.relevance: Arbitration clause perishes if agreement void ab initio.

precedents_cited.case_name: Tolaram Nathmull v. Birla Jute Mfg. Company Ltd.
Hussain Kasam Dada v. Vijayanagaram Commercial Association
Shiva Jute Baling Ltd. v. Hindley & Co. Ltd.
Daya v. Joint Controller of Imports and Exports

precedents_cited.relevance: Arbitration clause does not prevent assignment.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Arbitration Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Filing award, challenging existence/validity of arbitration agreement, grounds to set aside/modify/remit award.

statutes_cited.name: Forward Contracts (Regulation) Act, 1952
statutes_cited.relevance: Definitions of ready/forward/specific/non-transferable specific delivery contracts; prohibition of forward contracts except non-transferable specific; closure of contracts.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court rejected appellants' contentions on arbitration clause scope, estoppel, and proceeded to analyze contract as potentially illegal; text cuts off before explicit final order but upholds High Court approach on preliminary issues.

key_quotes.text: "Logically speaking, it is difficult to conceive how when an agreement found to be bad, any portion of it can held to be good. When the whole perishes, its parts also must perish."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Principle on arbitration clause validity tied to main contract.

key_quotes.text: "If the dispute is whether the contract which contains the clause has ever been entered into at all... or that it is void ab initio because... illegal, the arbitration clause cannot operate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: From Viscount Simon LC in Heyman v Darwins; core holding on void contracts.

key_quotes.text: "All forward contracts other than non-transferable specific delivery contracts for the sale or purchase of raw jute... shall be illegal."
key_quotes.speaker: court
